author: Stormtalon
title: Turbo-tastic
review:
Box/Instructions

The box is uniform with other Dimensions sets. The cover art shows Gamer Kid enjoying a game of Defender ready to pop another quarter in the machine.  The back art displays the 3 in 1 configurations of the Spyhunter car (1: Car, 2: Submarine, 3: Aircraft) and the Arcade Machine (1: Arcade Cabinet, 2: Flying shooter, 3: Pixel cannon) 

Parts

A strong assortment of greens and blacks for the Arcade machine and whites and blacks for the vehicle. The most striking are the printed tiles done in the style of the Defender video game from the 80's. 

Minifigures

Gamer Kid should have a real name.  His hair piece is pretty generic side part. Torso is unique with a black jacket and a green T-shirt with a yellow-green Invader in the center. He also has two accessories. 1: A single stud printed with a '5' to represent a game token. 2: A stud and single tube to represent a can of soda. 

The build

As with all Dimension sets, the instructions, beside the minifig, are displayed in the game. Both vehicle and device have a strong primary build and so-so alt modes.  The Spyhunter car is a delight to build and fun to take off the toy tag and roll around on its own. The Arcade Cabinet is a very creative build for a arcade game in minifig scale. The alt modes are forgettable and I didn't make them more than once just to try them out. 

The Gameplay

This is a Level Pack. You have a separate story mode to the game's main campaign. In a rundown part of town, Gamer Kid witnesses the old Retro Arcade explode with game sprites come to life. Only a skilled game can take on these vintage video games and tame the chaotic forces unleashed in the old arcade. 

In this expansion, you as Gamer Kid must work your way through the arcade to get to the final level. Each room has plenty of in-game obstacles that can be overcome using Gamer Kid's abilities.  Gamer has five related power-ups he can cycle through. (Laser Vision, Invisibility, Invincibility, Super Strength, Super Speed,  

Each room is controlled by a game that you have to jack into using the arcade cabinet and must play to a certain level in order to unlock the final level.  You play Spyhunter, Robotron, Joust, Super Sprint, Defender, Gauntlet and finally Rampage.  All are emulations of original games.  In addition, there is a hidden level that takes you into a level of Paperboy for several bonuses. 

There is replay value as you return to the Story Campaign to find Game Pads that unlock the 20+ games. The Midway Adventure world has more than a passing resemblance to Wreck-It-Ralph.

Overall opinion

Since this review comes after all the Year 1 sets have been released, I'd recommend this to any who have just bought the Starter Pack. Gamer Kid's multiple powers can substitute for 2 or 3 Fun pack characters.  Playing and mastering retro-80's games offer a challenge for those who have completed the main story.  The Spyhunter car is fun on its own and Arcade Cabinet has a ridiculous amount of detail. It is a great value added to Lego Dimensions.

author: Odeinoichus
title: MAME meets LEGO Dimensions for some Arcade Classics Fun.
review:
Set #71235 Midway Arcade Level Pack: LEGO Dimensions offers tons of universes and some of them are even based on Video Games. Or Video Game companies, this Level Pack was the final release for LEGO Dimensions. By which I mean the last Level Pack made available in Series 1 not the overall LEGO Dimensions theme. This is a great looking set too for fans of Retro Video Games, especially as it includes a large number of Arcade games to play for high scores and a fun diversion when you’re finished with the rest of the adventure in LEGO Dimensions.

Packaging

Discussing the packaging has become highly repetitive, however I adore this set’s box because it shows off a very classic looking Arcade on the front with Gamer Kid enjoying himself with a bit of Defender. Kids who grew up in the 80s will be taken in by the artwork on this set and really enjoy all the nostalgic memories it drums up.

Parts

This set features a lot of useful parts and a lot of familiar parts, but the best part by fall is the printed tiles for the Arcade Machine. If you want to make a huge MOC Arcade or a simple little fun area you’ll want multiples of those parts to make a few duplicate machines for your Minifigures to play with.

Minifigures

Gamer Kid: An original character who isn’t from any pre-existing IP, the Gamer Kid is the only new character outside of Lord Vortech and the robot dude I’m forgetting the name of at the moment, so he’s pretty plain looking, but also really awesome because of the design of his torso with an Alien on a green shirt from Defender (If I’m not mistaken) which fits the 80’s inspired Midway Arcade fans.

For accessories he includes a printed tile with 5 on it for a nickel or five cents I think. He also has a can of power, not soda pop, but a potion that grants him different abilities depending on the colour. (At least in-game.)

The build

G-6155 Spy Hunter: This build makes another car model, which is extremely satisfying. All of the car builds that have and use four wheels are very well done, and this is meant to evoke the vehicle in a classic Arcade game based around James Bond. (Though not officially known by that IP.) It’s a very impressive build and I can’t get behind it enough.

The Interdiver: Although resembling a submarine and with that name you’d think it could, this model is actually a glorified motor boat, which is pretty impressive. In fact all three models built with this particular toy item are very impressively designed and have few if any visible studs.

Aerial Spyhunter: Taking a car and turning it into a plane can be ridiculous or fun, this particular model is really fun. It is a little bit off from the parts use on the digital model unfortunately, but it does the best it can with what parts you are given and I think it’s pretty solid.

Arcade Machine: Using unique printed elements this is ultimately the best build in the set. You can take multiples and put them all over LEGO City, so Bricklinking the parts is a must. The model looks very appropriate and the printed elements just add to the fun of it, building the arcade cabinet is just awesome all around.

8-Bit Shooter: This model seems to be one of the alien characters from Defender… if you took the 8-Bit model and built it out of bricks this is probably what it would look like. It’s a fun build and hides all of the printed elements behind it, which could be a bit of a disservice for all those elements.

The Pixelator: I think this looks like it could be a model representing the laser device from Tron. If that laser device was an old arcade machine built into a laser. It’s actually a lot of fun to take the arcade machine and build this thing, it’s like you’re playing the game for real while riding the machine.

The completed model

G-6155 Spy Hunter & Alternative Builds: All three of these models are rock solid as I mentioned during the build discussion. This trio of models look great and are equally fun to build and play with on or off the toy pad.

Arcade Machine & Alternate Builds: The Arcade Machine is another solid trio of builds, I find that the machine itself is one that a lot of fans will enjoy over the other two, but each of the secondary models are pretty solid and fun to construct and play with.

The Digital Content

Level: Honestly I’m having a tough time recalling what the level is actually called, but the overall jist of it is that Gamer Kid is journeying through an old arcade while experiencing hints of the collision between Dimensions. He’s got a bunch of challenging puzzles to deal with involving attaching the Arcade Machine onto Arcade Stations and getting a certain number of points to achieve a medal in order to solve the puzzle and unlock that arcade cabinet in the adventure world. The level is fairly lengthy and the arcade games you have to play to pass some puzzles can cause some players to take longer to get through it.

Arcade Games are mostly simple, but can be tough, especially when you haven’t experienced them before or in a fairly long time. I haven’t played any games of this sort for a considerably long time, but I managed to succeed despite my short comings and get through the level. It helps that most of the arcade titles are not as obscure or difficult as some of the other titles on offer in this pack.

Adventure World: Midway Arcade World is a world based on Arcade video games, there are sections in the adventure world which are linked to a large number of iconic titles from the 1980s where you can solve puzzles, get gold bricks or studs and do other things which can cause tons of nostalgia. I’m a huge Gauntlet fan and their section is a great maze to travel through to get studs and access a few gold bricks.

The biggest draw of this Adventure World is the Arcade Stations, located in the central area near the gateway, this area is where you can use the Arcade Machine to play any number of classic arcade games from Midway when you want to distract yourself from the main adventure in LEGO Dimensions.

All of these Arcade titles have a dedicated border screen where you can see what that game would look like with LEGO elements and Minifigures used to represent the sprites found in the original games. This adds hours of game play to your title as you can easily lose yourself trying for the high scores.

Character & Vehicle Abilities: The Gamer Kid can use potions to power up and use certain abilities depending on which potion he drinks. These potions open up the ability to Destroy Cracked LEGO Objects, Invulnerability, Stealth, Speed and Laser… which I means can target Gold LEGO Objects and cut out shapes for puzzles or destroy them.

The Arcade Machine is used to access Arcade Stations, which unlocks Arcade games you can play for points to acquire studs and medals in the arcade game, which transfers the studs to the LEGO Dimensions characters. The 8-BS can fly, nothing else to do. The TP gives a Special Attack and that’s it.

The car from Spy Hunter can use Accelerator Switches and Tow-Bars, the TI has Water Travel and can Destroy Silver LEGO Objects and the AS accesses Flight Docks, Flight Cargo Hooks and can Destroy Gold LEGO Objects.

Overall opinion

With over 20 classic arcade titles from Midway Arcade and a fairly lengthy level with a very impressive adventure world and some great models to build, on top of having some very nice new elements with printed detailing for the Arcade Cabinet I would say this alone is one of the best offerings from LEGO Dimensions. You get to experience so much, and a lot of the games can be quite amusing and fun to engage in. Defender, Rampage, Paperboy, Spy Hunter, Joust and Joust 2, as well as such interesting arcade titles as Toobin’ where you ride the rapids on an inflatable inner tube. This is a must own set, not only for the physical content, but the digital content which add literal hours of game play to LEGO Dimensions. I strongly recommend this set.
